comments.commentBody: ISIS desecrates history and destroy world culture and the Koch Bros and their ilk desecrate nature and destroy our environment... What a 'great' situation....

First of all, IS has targeted and killed Palestinians in Yarmouk camp, Syria. Palestinians have NOT been friendly with IS and have fought against them, but you will notice IS is not attacking Israel who has helped them and who enjoys the divisions they cause in the Arab world and the eventual excuse they could become for further pain and suffering of Palestinians. The terrorists today are not Palestians who are humiliated, degraded, dispossesed of homes, lands, their very lives by a brutal occupation by Israel. Now THAT is terrorism.

the recent anniversary of the Hiroshima/Nagasaki atomic bombing by the U.S. afforded the former aggressors an opportunity to condemn and return of the aggression they fostered for 50 years in Asia.  Mohammed Omer tales his opportunity to bemoan the price of 60 years of Arab aggression against Israelis.  Gaza elected Hamas, a terrorist organization, and the West Bank is led by the PLO, the spawn of a terrorist organization.  Lest we forget, Arab terrorism is institutionalized and has many names, ISIS, Taliban, Al Qaeda, Hamas, Islamic Jihad, Boko Haram -- all of which are conscienceless killers.  Hamas does not care about Gazans or about loss of life.  Lest we forget...
It is certainly the operating principle of the military industrial complex. But it is Not what our country was founded on.

People who care about old stuff, become upset when antiquities are destroyed.They pay greater attention to antiquities than to people being killed.There is very little old stuff left, and a lot of people.

The US is only interested in regime change in Syria, it has armed ISIS, Turkey only cares about beating the PKK, while it lets ISIS use its border and arms ISIS, Israel hospitalizes ISIS soldiers, etc.

I think the US foreign policy is to sow chaos.It's certainly a good deal for armament-makers.

The actions of these barbarians have placed them outside the accords and conventions that apply to and govern those engaged in armed conflicts. It is time to consider the use of chemical or neutron weapons. While there are bound to be civillian casualties, even more are likely to die with the passage of time if this group is allowed to survive.
Who buys the oil they sell from the wells they have overtaken. Those people are equally culpable in the murder and destruction. Accomplices who remain secret, heinous and cowardly.
Sociopathic billionaires, I presume.
The international 1%.
Who is buying the antiquities when Isis sells them?

I used this recipe for the dough which I then used in another tart recipe. The dough was easy to make and roll out. It made just enough for a 9 inch tart pan. Post baking it was light and fluffy. Bittman rarely disappoints!!

Archaeological sites that survive are few. Progress and the rages of time usually destroy or obliterate the majority. What we have in situ or in museums is just a sample and we actually do not or cannot save it all. Ironically, excavation itself, by the act of excavation, can destroy.

Rarely, usually through luck and appropriate geographic and climatic conditions, a major site remains. Such was Palmyra (Tadmor), surviving much longer than its empire ever did and becoming certainly much more important than its empire.

However, its construction served as an outstanding example of the synthesis and symbiosis of East and West. That too apparently is becoming a thing of the past.

Sic transit gloria mundi.
Dum vivimus vivamus

" care for nothing, they respect nothing but violence, power and death."

Sounds like Putin too.
We are witnessing  absolute evil in action. What is being done is beyond barbarism, rooted in the very doctrine of fundamentalist Islam, propagated by Wahabism.
I wish they were alone doing that!
They do this to show that they are powerful.  If they will do this to ancient ruins, they will do this to you, too.  They care for nothing, they respect nothing but violence, power and death.

Don't you mean this is Obama's legacy, with his tacit approval of the so-called "Arab Spring"? We keep hearing about how Saddam Hussein was a "stabilizing force". Well, Iraq was somewhat stable, when he pulled our forces out in 2011. Egypt was somewhat stable, when he knee-capped Mubarak. Syria was stable, under Assad, when Obama drew his phony "red-line". Libya was stable, under Kaddafi, until we withdrew support (Benghazi anyone?). Worst foreign policy ever...

One of the definitions of Nihilism, according to Mirriam Webster: a doctrine or belief that conditions in the social organization are so bad as to make destruction desirable for its own sake independent of any constructive program or possibility.

Please don't call this twisted ideology Islamic. Religion doesn't enter into it. Conversion is never supposed to be compulsory. Christians and Jews were to be respected and unmolested if the word of Mohammad is to be respected. True Muslims believe Jesus was a prophet, even believing in the immaculate conception. Destroying churches is unislamic. Mohammad is spinning in his grave.

Btw, Mecca was a pagan place of worship before Mohammad rebranded it. If these monsters see no use for magnificent ancient sites, they simply aren't Muslims at all. Just look at what Constantinople became. Their most famous mosque was a magnificent church long before Turkish invasion.
All the West's cultural evolution has not taught us to respect and care for the very planet that bred us.

Just as there are CINOs (Christians in name only) there are MINOs (Muslims in name only)…this is simply not Islam at all by any stretch of the imagination. Claiming you are something does not necessarily make you one. For example the Nazis claimed they were good Christians which they were obviously not. I wonder when all the good Muslims will speak out against these MINOs who give them all bad reputations just as CINOs hurt all true Christians who sincerely walk their path daily. ISIS is a gang of sociopathic  criminals…far worse then barbarians. Matthew 7:16: By their fruit ye shall recognize them   …very clear & easily understood.

These priceless, irreplaceable objects are not just works of art or items of the past, they represent the evolution of Western Civilization. ISIS wishes to erase the record of our cultural evolution. As far as they are concerned, nothing humankind has done ever mattered except their twisted and sickening barbaric brand of Islam. Time began with the birth of their caliphate.

This is a new low in barbarism. When I first learned many years ago of the burning of the ancient library of Alexandria in Egypt, I felt reassured that modern people would never commit such horrible acts and not recognize such cultural and historical value of artifacts. ISIS is showing us once again that they are not a members of the family of modern people. They not only seek to destroy life, they seek to destroy the fabric of society, of social order. By destroying these ancient relics, they prove that point with absolute accuracy.

@ Maui Yankee, Maui
Of course you are entitled to your own opinion and response. But it does betray a certain lack of understanding of cultures other than your own.
The destruction of Palmyra is nothing less than a loss to Humanity. The beauty and the art of these ancient civilizations is now gone forever, and its likes shall never be seen again.
Not to mention the underage sex slave trade and christian beheadings, so yea, destroying antiquities speaks "volumes" about the savagery of these people.
I think of them as deranged Homo Sapiens and not evolved Human Beings…there is a major difference between the two.

I wish I was fluent in several other languages because I cannot find English words or phrases that adequately convey the degree of to-the-bone contempt I feel for these despicable so-called humans.  I'm sure other, older languages born of ancient cultures that faced such sickening behavior must feature some divine phrases.
We didn't allow military members of the Nazi party to continue either. Then again we were dealing with people who don't put religion and tribalism in front of reality.

"...the grinding slaughter of human beings, the ravaging of irreplaceable antiquities..."  And yet the Middle East, Russia, China, America, Britain, France and the rest of the world stand and do nothing.  Where is the United Nations?  It's showing its value to be sure.  If ISIS attacked Israel, perhaps this small country, with it collective memories, would fight back. I suspect that they would destroy ISIS with a fury that only the slaughtered themselves know.  I look to Israel.  All the rest are cowards.
Barbarism must be defeated in a way they recognize. Force has a legitimate place defending the innocent and civilization. The Nazi ovens didn't stop through negotiation.

I had the opportunity to visit Palmyra in 2006 and have very fond memories of the people, landscape and especially the antiquities.  So it is with great sadness I read of the news coming from Syria these past years.   There are no obvious answers on how to resolve this - violence begets violence and ISIS, al Asad, etc. do not seem to be interested in anything peace-related.  I grieve for the people of Syria and for the rest of us who are losing precious details of history.
The Institute of Medicine uses 3.7 liters of water consumption a day for an adult man, and 2.7 liters a day for an adult woman.
Why is it a U.N. problem? And exactly where is the rest of the Islamic world?

"The UN truly useful...."

Hah. Now THERE is a joke.

"When bad men combine, the good must associate; else they will fall one by one, an unpitied sacrifice in a contemptible struggle".
Edmund Burke

I know who are bad guys here but not sure who are good

Isn't remedying this a job for the UN?

Once in a while the UN has an opportunity to make itself truly useful. This is one of those times.

However, it's important to know that the original recommendation of eight, 8 oz. glasses of water a day was not based on any scientific evidence or population study.  It was just someone's judgement call.  On reflection, it makes no sense that someone hiking in the hills near Phoenix, AZ, would have the exact same water requirement as someone resting in the shade in WA State's Olympic Peninsula Rain Forest.  This was just another example of a well-intentioned D.C. bureaucrat, with some scientific background, grandiosely pretending to know what was best for everyone, everywhere.

I made a few modifications to this to enable greater ease.  First I used a pastry recipe from Mark Bittman. His flaky pie crust used more common, everyday pantry items and was easier to roll out. The second thing that was different was I used tomaties, leeks and mozzarella (again what I had in my fridge). Everything came out wonderfully and was a huge hit. Great to make for a breakfast on the go or quick dinner. The two eggs is just enough but you may need three depending on your ingredients.
"All we can ever learn about all those who have gone before us is what we learn from the art they have left us." John Dos Passos (more or less). Ignorance, heavily armed, wins again.

Blacks (and white) incarcerated for drug are overwhelmingly dealers of drug, rather than users who are not drug dealers. Correcting for the difference in rates of drug dealing, this anomaly disappears. Blacks have higher rates of dealing drugs than whites, and therefore higher rates of drug-related incarceration. The user rate is not the relevant variable for explaining incarceration rates.

Those who claims black students simply commit more infractions apparently are not aware that many more whites than blacks use illicit drugs, yet blacks are incarcerated at more than more the rate as whites for the same offense.

As such, it is possible that black students are being treated unfairly; much as we don not like to admit it, it happens. I used to teach English in a Title I high school in the deep, red American South, mostly comprised of whites, but where some of my colleagues would sneer only black students fro receiving free or reduced-cost breakfasts and lunches.

Seems like some of those same colleagues have shown up here to comment.
I call it a rush to interpret everything as racism despite the facts not being in yet, or in many cases despite the facts themselves (Michael Brown).

Lucy,
To question deeper means to have scientific studies done on such questions. There are in fact such studies but whenever the results do not match the expectations of the PC crowd, they are branded as racist.

One of the most emailed articles in today's paper is 'The case for teaching Ignorance". The author states "answers don't merely resolve questions; they provoke new ones". Most commenters on that article praise the approach of not stopping at simple answers but probing more deeply into what we take as truth or believe.

In that same paper the top read article is about there being very little scientific data supporting our need for 8 glasses of water a day. Most commenters present anecdotal evidence to dispel the data presented.

The first few commenters on this article about higher expulsion rates of Black students seems to have all the "answers",'facts", "beliefs" i.e Blacks are trouble makers and do not take responsibility for themselves etc. There is no pause for questioning deeper to find answers or even resolve harder questions. There is no anecdotal "evidence" of knowing a Black child who was expelled and why. Just statements of "facts" from our friendly NYT commenters. And we wonder if racism exist?

There has been no change in Cuba since Obama's rapprochement began in December of 2014. The repression has gotten worse for dissidents. Would you ask a Holocaust survivor to forget the "bad blood" of the past? As with the victims of the Nazis, Castro's victims demand justice. Castro has executed 14,000 innocent Cubans without trial and 77,000 have drowned in the Straits of Florida while attempting to flee the genocidal regime. Today, half of Cuba's 12 million citizens have stated they would leave Cuba if they were permitted. All the tourism and commerce in the world will not change the sociopolitical or economic conditions of the average Cuban. This is a historical and political fact that Obama ignores. Freedom is the fount from which all progress and success has its genesis. Civil liberties and respect for human rights will always trump business interests.

NYT: Please do not delete and censor this comment. If you do, you are replicating the tactics of Castro's totalitarian regime. It is wrong and violates the individual's
right to free speech. I speak the truth.

Freedom for Cuba! Justice for the Cuban people!
